awd_titl_txt: Gauge Theory and Symplectic Geometry in Dimensions 3 and 4
awd_abstract_narration:
Gauge theory has played an important role in the study of three- and four-dimensional manifolds in the last three decades. Investigation of invariants from gauge theory has revealed many interesting geometric and topological properties of these manifolds. Meanwhile, pseudo-holomorphic curves in symplectic geometry have been used to introduce other closely related invariants. The projects outlined in this proposal are organized into five topics, each of which exploit the recently proved correspondences between invariants of three- and four-dimensional manifolds from Seiberg-Witten gauge theory and symplectic geometry to reveal more about the geometry and topology of these manifolds. To be more explicit, two of the topics investigate the contact topology of three-dimensional manifolds and the existence/uniqueness of symplectic structures on certain types of four-dimensional manifolds. Another topic concerns the conjectured correspondence between the Seiberg-Witten and Ozsvath-Szabo invariants of smooth four-dimensional manifolds. The remaining two topics develop and study Floer homological invariants of knots and three-dimensional manifolds with boundary from Seiberg-Witten gauge theory and symplectic geometry, respectively. 

Both gauge theory and symplectic geometry have their origins in theoretical physics, where they are used as mathematical frameworks to describe a classical or quantum dynamical system. In particular, quantized gauge theory plays a central role in understanding the dynamics of our universe through what is known as the standard model. The effort to determine the shape of our universe, which we perceive as a four-dimensional space--three spatial dimensions and one time dimension--has over time created a successful collaboration between mathematics and physics. The study in the abstract setting by mathematicians of these mathematical frameworks used by physicists not only creates new research directions in mathematics but also provides new perspectives for physicists to employ in their research. The research outlined in this proposal aims to contribute to this collaboration by continuing the study of interactions between Seiberg-Witten gauge theory and symplectic geometry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to investigate further relations among various invariants of three- and four-dimensional spaces and geometric structures. Invariants are a way to quantify intrinsic properties of spaces and geometric structures that remain unchanged under deformations. Investigation and discovery of such properties and patterns help us determine the shape and dynamics of our universe, which we perceive as a four-dimensional space—three spatial dimensions plus the time dimension.
The main outcomes of this research are the content of four research articles, one of which is in preparation to be made publicly available soon. The first is a joint article of the PI with Steven Sivek where they investigate the sensitivity of an invariant for three-dimensional spaces with borders to certain geometric data in the background. Thanks to an appendix by Clifford H. Taubes, they prove that the invariant is insensitive to the geometric data, hence it is mainly determined by the shape of the three-dimensional space. Meanwhile, Taubes’s appendix sets up foundations for a theory to produce invariants of unbounded three-dimensional spaces.
The remaining three articles are joint with Gordana Matic, Jeremy Van Horn-Morris, and Andy Wand. In these articles, the PI and his co-authors introduce refinements of some invariants for certain geometric structures on three-dimensional spaces, called contact structures. These refinements have several desirable properties and are algorithmically computable. One of their goals is to explore to what extent their invariant can distinguish among contact structures. Furthermore, there are variations of their invariant that can be defined for other types of spaces and objects, such as knots. 
Another outcome of the project is a research article joint with Jonathan Hanselman and Tye  Lidman and it addresses the question of what values of certain invariants of three-dimensional spaces, called Heegaard Floer homology, can be realized. Answers to such questions, referred to as ``geography problems,’’ enrich our understanding of the strength and limitations of these invariants.
The outcomes of the project are made publicly made available in the electronic preprint repository arXiv.org and the PI gave several research talks on his work in seminars and conferences, serving the goal of dissemination of knowledge and ideas. The PI also co-organized seminars and special sessions in conferences where he invited speakers from under-represented groups. Such activities also helped in training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in the field. 


Last Modified: 10/28/2017
Modified by: Cagatay Kutluhan
